p: Based on species‐specific, generalized linear mixed model analyses (GLMM) with time as a fixed factor and square as a random factor, 87 species (37.0%) showed a significant ( p < .05) increase in numbers of occupied squares and 82 species (34.9%) a decrease, and 66 species (28.1%) did not show any significant change (see Table S1). The numbers of decreased, stable, or increased species in terms of occupied squares did not significantly differ between major bird species orders (χ 2 = 8.54, p = .201, df = 6), between passerines (Passeriformes), shorebirds (Charadriiformes and Gruiformes), waterfowl (Anseriformes), and birds of prey (raptors Falconiformes and owls Strigiformes) (Fig. 2).
